content.title: Hepatic Transplant Vascular Techniques
content.definition: Vascular anastomotic techniques for liver transplantation, including caval, portal venous, and hepatic arterial reconstruction.

key_concepts.description: Bicaval (complete IVC resection with end-to-end anastomoses) vs piggyback (preservation of recipient IVC with side-to-side cavocavostomy).
End-to-end donor to recipient portal vein. May require conduit for thrombosed recipient PV.
Most variable component. Multiple techniques based on donor and recipient anatomy.

bicaval_technique.indication: Classic technique, fulminant hepatic failure with hemodynamic instability
bicaval_technique.anastomoses: Suprahepatic IVC end-to-end, infrahepatic IVC end-to-end
bicaval_technique.venovenous_bypass: May be needed during anhepatic phase

piggyback_technique.indication: Preferred at most centers, preserves recipient IVC
piggyback_technique.anastomosis: Side-to-side cavocavostomy of donor suprahepatic cuff to recipient hepatic vein confluence
piggyback_technique.advantages: Shorter anhepatic phase, no need for venovenous bypass, hemodynamic stability

standard.technique: End-to-end donor to recipient portal vein
standard.growth_factor: May leave interrupted suture for expansion

options: Jump graft from SMV using donor iliac vein
Cavoportal hemitransposition (portal vein to vena cava)

recipient_arteries.assessment: Palpation for pulse and quality, consider intraoperative Doppler

donor_arteries.standard: Celiac trunk with aortic patch (Carrel patch)
donor_arteries.variant_anatomy: May require bench reconstruction of replaced or accessory hepatic arteries

techniques.branch_patch: Most common - donor celiac to recipient arterial branch
techniques.aortic_conduit: Interposition graft from infrarenal aorta to donor celiac when recipient artery unusable

portal_vein_thrombosis.management: Thrombectomy, anticoagulation, retransplantation if graft failure

living_donor_considerations.hepatic_artery: Often small, single - requires microsurgical technique
living_donor_considerations.hepatic_vein: May require venoplasty or graft extension

learning_objectives: Compare bicaval and piggyback caval techniques
Describe options for hepatic artery reconstruction including aortic conduit
Explain management of portal vein thrombosis in liver transplant recipients
List vascular complications and their management
clinical_pearls: Piggyback technique is hemodynamically superior for most patients
Hepatic artery thrombosis is the most feared vascular complication
Confirm arterial flow with Doppler before abdominal closure
Aortic conduit is salvage technique for arterial inflow problems
